message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aortic stenosis is associated with a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotid arteries. The other options are not specific to aortic stenosis - an S3 can be present in many cardiac conditions, murmur radiation to the axilla can occur in mitral regurgitation or tricuspid regurgitation, and asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy can be seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the dyspnea and chest pain, along with the new onset murmur suggest aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis often causes the murmur to radiate to the carotid arteries bilaterally. The presence of S3 is associated with heart failure, but not specific to aortic stenosis. Murmur radiating to axilla can indicate other conditions such as mitral regurgitation. Asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy is a sign of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is not specific to aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotid arteries bilaterally. The presence of an S3 or murmur radiation to the axilla is not specific to aortic stenosis, while asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy may be seen in other conditions as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of exertional dyspnea, substernal chest pain, and a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space suggest aortic stenosis. The fact that the murmur radiates to the carotid arteries bilaterally is the most supportive evidence for this diagnosis. Presence of S3 and asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy are not specific for aortic stenosis, while murmur radiation to the axilla is more indicative of mitral regurgitation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space suggests aortic stenosis. The fact that it was not heard at the last appointment six months ago indicates that it is a new finding. The murmur radiating to the carotid arteries bilaterally is a classic sign of aortic stenosis. Asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy may suggest other cardiac conditions. The presence of an S3 may be a sign of heart failure but is not specific to aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom of exertional dyspnea and substernal chest pain, along with the new presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the right 2nd intercostal space, suggest aortic stenosis. A common characteristic of aortic stenosis is that the murmur radiates to the carotid arteries bilaterally. The presence of S3 is more indicative of heart failure, the murmur radiating to axilla is more indicative of mitral regurgitation, and asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that radiates to the carotid arteries due to the turbulent blood flow through the aortic valve. The presence of S3 may suggest heart failure, but it is not specific to aortic stenosis. Murmur radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, and asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including exertional dyspnea and substernal chest pain, along with the murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space, suggest aortic stenosis. The murmur radiating to the carotid arteries bilaterally is a classic finding in aortic stenosis. Option A is incorrect as presence of S3 is common in heart failure and not specific for aortic stenosis. Option C is incorrect as murmur radiating to axilla is a finding in mitral regurgitation. Option D is incorrect as asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy can be seen in various cardiac diseases and is not specific for aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space suggests aortic stenosis. The murmur radiating to the carotid arteries bilaterally is characteristic of aortic stenosis. Presence of S3 is more indicative of heart failure. Murmur radiating to the axilla is more indicative of mitral regurgitation. Asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy can be seen in aortic stenosis but is not specific.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to carotid arteries bilaterally. The other options are not specific to aortic stenosis. The presence of S3 suggests heart failure, murmur radiating to the axilla suggests mitral regurgitation, and asymmetric ventricular hypertrophy suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
